QUESTION

What is the correct question tag for the sentence: ‚ÄúShe ought to apologise, ‚Ä¶‚Äù?

Technically, for modal verbs such as ‚Äúought to‚Äù, ‚Äúhave to‚Äù and ‚Äúused to‚Äù, the tag uses the modal verb without ‚Äúto‚Äù. The ‚Äúto‚Äù is actually part of the main verb. So, the correct form would be:
She ought to apologise, oughtn‚Äôt she?
This follows the same pattern as:
She has to apologise, hasn‚Äôt she?
With ‚Äúused to‚Äù, the techncally correct form is:
She used to apologise, usedn‚Äôt she?
However, most native English speakers today would not use this form. We would say:
She used to apologise, didn‚Äôt she?

QUESTION

Is this sentence grammatically correct and meaningful? Is it something that a native English speaker would say, " I saw this shirt cheaper in anothet shop"?

I‚Äôm sure I‚Äôve said, ‚ÄúI saw it cheaper somewhere else,‚Äù more than once in my life when talking about some item, so someone might well say your sentence too. The sense is ‚ÄúI saw an identical shirt that was cheaper in another shop.‚Äù
If you or the other person is thinking of buying the shirt, perhaps ‚ÄúI‚Äôve seen it cheaper‚Ä¶‚Äù is more likely. That is, it‚Äôs currently available at a lower price in another store.
We can use ‚Äòget,‚Äô ‚Äòbuy‚Äô and ‚Äòfind‚Äô the same way: ‚ÄúYou can get/buy/find this shirt cheaper at Tom‚Äôs Haberdashery.‚Äù

entry.title: Is it correct if I say, "I have been working for quite a company"? [Quite+a/an+...
entry.content:
Is it correct if I say, "I have been working for quite a company"? [Quite+a/an+ noun]

Yes, ‚Äúquite‚Äù can be used in that way, that is, in front of an article followed by a noun‚Äîand we use it like that all the time in English. However, the sentence itself is somewhat unnatural in English. Here ‚Äúquite a company‚Äù expresses admiration for the company. Take a look at these sentences:
That‚Äôs quite an achievement!
He‚Äôs quite a singer!
Both sentences are meant to express the speaker‚Äôs admiration or to say that the speaker is impressed by the achievement or the person‚Äôs ability to sing. These are natural in English. However, we rarely find ourselves needing to express admiration for a company‚Äîeven if it is the company that we have been working for.
Here are some other, more natural, examples:
It‚Äôs been quite a day! (‚Üí an eventful, stressful, or memorable day, depending on the context)
I ended up with quite a headache after listening to all that loud, pounding music. (‚Üí here, ‚Äúquite‚Äù can indicate that the headache was severe, or that it was more than just an ordinary headache)
It was quite a large room. (‚Üí not ‚Äúvery‚Äù large, but a little bit less than very large)
When ‚Äúquite‚Äù is used in this way it functions as an intensifier of the noun. It is similar to ‚Äúsuch‚Äù and ‚Äúrather‚Äù in the way we position it in front of the article:
The room was in quite a mess.
The room was in such a mess.
The room was in rather a mess.
Depending on the context, the intensifying function of ‚Äúquite‚Äù may also serve to express admiration through the intensification.

QUESTION
Is this sentence grammatically correct and meaningful? Is it something that a native...
entry.content:
QUESTION

Is this sentence grammatically correct and meaningful? Is it something that a native English speaker would say, "The police arrested the tourist on discovering his passport was fake"?

Yes, the general sentence structure is correct and the overall sentence makes sense. There are some usage errors in the sentence, but they do not affect its overall structure and meaning.
One usage error is ‚Äúthe police‚Äù. This term refers to the whole institution of law enforcement and we use it as a general reference to the entire police force or to a group consisting of members of this force. In this particular context, it is unlikely that a group representing the police force performed the arrest. In a situation such as this one, the arrest would be most likely to be performed by a single police officer. So, we would naturally say:
The police officer arrested the tourist ‚Ä¶
The other usage issue is the use of the structure ‚Äúon discovering ‚Ä¶‚Äù. This is a rather formal way of expressing the idea. It is grammatically correct and, of course, it can be used, but most native English speakers would not use it in ordinary conversation. It might be found in a newspaper article or in a report of some kind. We would use an adverb clause of time with ‚Äúwhen‚Äù, like this:
The police officer arrested the tourist when she (or he) discovered that his passport was fake.
